children.text: Give each use case a unique numeric identifier. State a concise name for the use case that indicates the value the use case would provide to some user. Begin with an action verb, followed by an object.
Enter the name of the person who initially wrote this use case and the date it was written.

An actor is a person or other entity external to the software system being specified who interacts with the system and performs use cases to accomplish something of value. Different actors often correspond to different user classes, or roles. Name the primary actor that will be initiating this use case and any other secondary actors (humans or systems) that will participate in the use case’s execution.

data.heading: Description
data.text: The system dynamically generates an optimized waste/recycling collection route for workers based on live bin data, current traffic conditions, and operational constraints. The route adapts in real time to changes, ensuring efficient coverage and minimal missed pickups.

children.text: Provide a brief description of the reason for and outcome of this use case, or a high-level description of the sequence of actions and the outcome of executing the use case.

data.heading: Trigger
data.text: Worker logs into the mobile app at the start of shift and selects “Start Route”.

children.text: Identify the event or user action that initiates the use case. This trigger alerts the system to test the preconditions so it can judge whether to proceed with execution.

List any activities that must take place, or any conditions that must be true, before the use case can be started. The system must be able to test each precondition. Number each precondition. Example: PRE-1. User’s identity has been authenticated.

Describe the state of the system at the successful conclusion of the use case execution. Label each postcondition in the form POST-X, where X is a sequence number. Example: POST-1. Price of item in the database has been updated with the new value.

Provide a description of the user actions and corresponding system responses that will take place during execution of the use case under normal, expected conditions. This dialogue sequence will lead to accomplishing the goal stated in the use case name and description. Show a numbered list of actions performed by the actor, alternating with responses provided by the system. The normal flow is numbered “X.0”, where “X” is the Use Case ID.

Document other successful usage scenarios that can take place within this use case. State the alternative flow, and describe any differences in the sequence of steps that take place. Number each alternative flow in the form “X.Y”, where “X” is the Use Case ID and Y is a sequence number for the alternative flow. For example, “5.3” would indicate the third alternative flow for use case number 5. Indicate where each alternative flow would branch off from the normal flow, and if pertinent, where it would rejoin the normal flow.

Describe any anticipated error conditions that could occur during execution of the use case and how the system is to respond to those conditions. Number each alternative flow in the form “X.Y.EZ”, where “X” is the Use Case ID, Y indicates the normal (0) or alternative (>0) flow during which this exception could take place, “E” indicates an exception, and “Z” is a sequence number for the exceptions. For example “5.0.E2” would indicate the second exception for the normal flow for use case number 5. Indicate where in the normal (or an alternative) flow each exception could occur.
Indicate the relative priority of implementing the functionality required to allow this use case to be executed. Use the same priority scheme as that used for other requirements.
List any business rules that influence this use case. Don’t include the business rule text here, just its identifier so the reader can find it in another repository when needed.
List any assumptions that were made regarding this use case or how it might execute.

Identify any additional pertinent requirements or constraints for the use case, such as quality attributes. Describe what should happen if the use case execution fails for some unanticipated or systemic reason (e.g., loss of network access, timeout). If the use case results in a durable state change in a database or the outside world, state whether the change is rolled back, completed correctly, partially completed with a known state, or left in an undetermined state as a result of the exception.

data.text:
Primary Actor

Use Cases

 Collection Worker

 Optimize Collection Route, Confirm Pickup

 Resident

 Report Missed Pickup/Issue, Track Recycling Rewards

 City Administrator

 Monitor Fleet Dashboard, Update Collection Parameters

 Supervisor 

 Approve Exception Reports, Audit Route Changes


Technician


Sensor Health Monitoring, Maintenance Dispatch

Bin Sensor Network (API)


Provide bin fill data, Alert for overflow

Traffic Data API

Provide real-time traffic status, Update optimal route


Scheduled Collection Event

Trigger daily/weekly collection batch assignment

data.heading: Use Case Template
data.text:
ID and Name:

UC-01: Optimize Collection Route

Author:

Ajay Ludher

Date Created:

Oct 23, 2025

Primary Actor:

Collection Worker

Secondary Actors:

Traffic Data API, Supervisor

Description:

The system generates an optimized waste/recycling collection route for the worker using real-time bin sensor data and current traffic conditions. The worker is guided in real time, ensuring efficient service, fewer missed pickups, and improved operational efficiency.

Trigger:

Worker logs into the mobile app and selects “Start Route” at the beginning of their shift.

Preconditions:

PRE-1. Worker’s identity is authenticated in the mobile app.

PRE-2. Vehicle assignment and pre-trip checklist are completed.

PRE-3. Bin sensor network and traffic data API are online.​

Postconditions:

POST-1. Completed pickup events are logged to the system and available to supervisor and city administrator.

POST-2. Route completion and any rerouting events are recorded for audit and reporting.   

Normal Flow:

  1. Worker opens the “Route” feature in the app.
  2. System fetches latest sensor and traffic data, computes the optimized route.
  3. Route map with navigation is shown to worker; worker follows the instructions.
  4. System monitors progress, sends alerts if route conditions change (e.g., bin fills, traffic delay).
  5. Worker confirms each pickup in app; data is logged in real-time.
  6. After last stop, worker reviews summary; route completion is entered in the system.

Alternative Flows:

  1. Worker loses connection—app switches to offline mode, uses cached route, enables local logging.
  2. Unexpected bin overflow detected—system pushes rerouting and notification to worker.
  3. Traffic API fails—system falls back to static routing and logs the event.

Exceptions:

  1. ​Bin sensor returns error—system skips the bin, logs incident, sends an alert to technician.
  2. Vehicle breakdown—worker pauses route, sends status; supervisor receives immediate alert.
  3. Worker unable to access route—system provides emergency contact and escalates to support.

Priority:

 High

Business Rules:

​BR-01: Only bins meeting fill threshold are scheduled for collection.

BR-02: Any route deviation must be confirmed by the supervisor.

Assumptions:

  • ​Network infrastructure and bin sensors work reliably.
  • Traffic data API is consistently available during route calculation.

Other Information:

All route changes, pickups, exceptions, and completion events are auditable. Offline work automatically syncs when reconnected.

data.text:
ID and Name:

UC-02: Report Missed Pickup/Issue

Author:

Ajay Ludher

Date Created:

Oct 23, 2025

Primary Actor:

Resident

Secondary Actors:

City Administrator, Supervisor

Description:

A resident uses the mobile or web app to report a missed garbage collection, a blocked bin, or contamination. The report is processed, and relevant administrative and field staff are notified for follow-up and resolution.

Trigger:

Resident selects “Report Issue” in the SWMRS app or web portal and submits incident details.

Preconditions:

PRE-1. Resident is authenticated in the system (app/web).

PRE-2. The current day’s collection schedule is available.

PRE-3. The system is online and able to receive incident submissions.

Postconditions:

POST-1. The issue report is logged and assigned a unique tracking ID.

POST-2. The City Administrator and relevant Supervisor are notified.

POST-3. Issue is visible to the resident in their app portal until resolution.

Normal Flow:

  1. Resident selects report type (missed pickup, blockage, contamination, etc.) in the app.
  2. Resident describes the issue and optionally provides a photo.
  3. Resident confirms location/address and submits the report.
  4. System generates confirmation and issue tracking ID for resident.
  5. System routes the issue to the appropriate administrator and supervisor for review.
  6. Supervisor reviews and assigns field response or schedules corrective action.
  7. Resident receives updates or resolution notice in-app/on web portal.

Alternative Flows:

  1. Resident is unable to submit a photo—system allows issue submission with only a text description.
  2. If no collection was scheduled for reported date/address, system notifies resident of scheduling mismatch but still logs issue for review.

Exceptions:

  1. Resident submits duplicate report—system checks for similar open issues and prompts resident to view status or confirm sharing new evidence.
  2. System temporarily offline—system stores the report locally and submits automatically once connected; resident is informed of delayed submission.
  3. Address cannot be matched—resident prompted to correct or select location manually.

Priority:

 High

Business Rules:

BR-05: Only authenticated residents can submit formal collection complaints.

BR-06: Supervisors must address missed pickup issues within defined SLA timeframe.

Assumptions:

  • Residents have access to a smartphone or computer with internet connection.
  • Complaint submission workflow aligns with city escalation policy.

Other Information:

Reports and updates are auditable. System auto-reminds supervisor if issue not addressed within SLA. Duplicate submissions help build history for persistent problems.

Description:

The system generates an optimized waste/recycling collection route for the worker using real-time bin sensor data and current traffic conditions. The worker is guided in real time, ensuring efficient service, fewer missed pickups, and improved operational efficiency.

Trigger:

Worker logs into the mobile app and selects “Start Route” at the beginning of their shift.

Preconditions:

PRE-1. Worker’s identity is authenticated in the mobile app.

PRE-2. Vehicle assignment and pre-trip checklist are completed.

PRE-3. Bin sensor network and traffic data API are online.​

Postconditions:

POST-1. Completed pickup events are logged to the system and available to supervisor and city administrator.

POST-2. Route completion and any rerouting events are recorded for audit and reporting.   

Normal Flow:

  1. Worker opens the “Route” feature in the app.
  2. System fetches latest sensor and traffic data, computes the optimized route.
  3. Route map with navigation is shown to worker; worker follows the instructions.
  4. System monitors progress, sends alerts if route conditions change (e.g., bin fills, traffic delay).
  5. Worker confirms each pickup in app; data is logged in real-time.
  6. After last stop, worker reviews summary; route completion is entered in the system.

Alternative Flows:

  1. Worker loses connection—app switches to offline mode, uses cached route, enables local logging.
  2. Unexpected bin overflow detected—system pushes rerouting and notification to worker.
  3. Traffic API fails—system falls back to static routing and logs the event.

Exceptions:

  1. ​Bin sensor returns error—system skips the bin, logs incident, sends an alert to technician.
  2. Vehicle breakdown—worker pauses route, sends status; supervisor receives immediate alert.
  3. Worker unable to access route—system provides emergency contact and escalates to support.

Priority:

 High

Business Rules:

​BR-01: Only bins meeting fill threshold are scheduled for collection.

BR-02: Any route deviation must be confirmed by the supervisor.

Assumptions:

  • ​Network infrastructure and bin sensors work reliably.
  • Traffic data API is consistently available during route calculation.

Other Information:

All route changes, pickups, exceptions, and completion events are auditable. Offline work automatically syncs when reconnected.

ID and Name:

UC-03: Track Recycling Rewards

Author:

Ajay Ludher

Date Created:

Oct 23, 2025

Primary Actor:

Resident

Secondary Actors:

Local Business Partner, City Administrator

Description:

A resident uses the mobile or web app to report a missed garbage collection, a blocked bin, or contamination. The report is processed, and relevant administrative and field staff are notified for follow-up and resolution.

Trigger:

Resident selects “Report Issue” in the SWMRS app or web portal and submits incident details.

Preconditions:

PRE-1. Resident is authenticated in the system (app/web).

PRE-2. The current day’s collection schedule is available.

PRE-3. The system is online and able to receive incident submissions.

Postconditions:

POST-1. The issue report is logged and assigned a unique tracking ID.

POST-2. The City Administrator and relevant Supervisor are notified.

POST-3. Issue is visible to the resident in their app portal until resolution.

Normal Flow:

  1. Resident selects report type (missed pickup, blockage, contamination, etc.) in the app.
  2. Resident describes the issue and optionally provides a photo.
  3. Resident confirms location/address and submits the report.
  4. System generates confirmation and issue tracking ID for resident.
  5. System routes the issue to the appropriate administrator and supervisor for review.
  6. Supervisor reviews and assigns field response or schedules corrective action.
  7. Resident receives updates or resolution notice in-app/on web portal.

Alternative Flows:

  1. Resident is unable to submit a photo—system allows issue submission with only a text description.
  2. If no collection was scheduled for reported date/address, system notifies resident of scheduling mismatch but still logs issue for review.

Exceptions:

  1. Resident submits duplicate report—system checks for similar open issues and prompts resident to view status or confirm sharing new evidence.
  2. System temporarily offline—system stores the report locally and submits automatically once connected; resident is informed of delayed submission.
  3. Address cannot be matched—resident prompted to correct or select location manually.

Priority:

 High

Business Rules:

BR-05: Only authenticated residents can submit formal collection complaints.

BR-06: Supervisors must address missed pickup issues within defined SLA timeframe.

Assumptions:

  • Residents have access to a smartphone or computer with internet connection.
  • Complaint submission workflow aligns with city escalation policy.

Other Information:

Reports and updates are auditable. System auto-reminds supervisor if issue not addressed within SLA. Duplicate submissions help build history for persistent problems.
